clinical_study.brief_title: Feasibility of Using a Structured Daily Diary
clinical_study.official_title: Feasibility of Using a Structured Daily Diary to Assess Mood, Stressful Events, Support, Substance Use, and Sexual Behavior in HIV-Positive Young Men Who Have Sex With Men

lead_sponsor.agency: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

clinical_study.source: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

brief_summary.textblock: This protocol explores the feasibility and acceptability of using two daily diary methods to analyze state-dependent variables and psychosocial health outcomes in Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV)-positive young men who have sex with men (YMSM). The study will explore the potential of diaries for use in feedback-based interventions.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants who Complete the 66-Day Structured Daily Diary
primary_outcome.description: The first primary objective of this study is to implement a 66-day structured daily diary with 90 HIV-positive YMSM to explore relationships among daily mood, stressful events, social support, substance use, sexual behavior, and adherence to ART among youth who are currently prescribed to take medication.

primary_outcome.measure: Rate of Completion of 66-Day Structured Daily Diary by Modality Type
primary_outcome.description: The second primary objective is to explore the feasibility and acceptability of using two daily diary modalities (IVR and IWR) as (1) a novel method of data collection in research involving HIV-positive YMSM, and (2) a potential tool to provide personalized feedback and/or assist with self-monitoring among HIV-positive YMSM.

primary_outcome.measure: Reasons and Rate of for Non-completion of 66-Day Structured Daily Diary
primary_outcome.description: The second primary objective is to explore the feasibility and acceptability of using two daily diary modalities (IVR and IWR) as (1) a novel method of data collection in research involving HIV-positive YMSM, and (2) a potential tool to provide personalized feedback and/or assist with self-monitoring among HIV-positive YMSM.

secondary_outcome.measure: Participant Responses to how Diary can Provide Personalized Feedback on Triggers to Risk Behaviors
secondary_outcome.description: The secondary objective of this study is to obtain feedback from HIV-positive YMSM on how the diary could be used to provide personalized feedback on triggers to risk behaviors, such as substance use, unprotected sexual behavior, and poor medication adherence. These data will be obtained through debriefing interviews.

arm_group.arm_group_label: A: Begin with Interactive Voice Response (IVR) System
arm_group.description: Group A participants are randomized the IVR system as Modality #1. After 33 days of diary completion using IVR, they switch to the interactive web response system (IWR)as Modality #2.

arm_group.arm_group_label: B: Begin with Interactive Web Response (IWR) System
arm_group.description: Group B participants are randomized to the IWR system as Modality #1. After 33 days of diary completion using IWR, they switch to the interactive voice response (IVR)system as Modality #2.

intervention.description: The intervention is a structured daily diary to describe fluctuations in key psychological and behavioral variables impacting daily risk behavior among HIV-positive young men who have sex with men (YMSM), aged 16 to 24 years old who engage in substance use and sexual risk behaviors.
